speech_and_audio_cues_description: At 0:29, the officer asks 'What's up?' to a civilian. At 0:34, another civilian asks 'Are you gonna arrest me?' and the officer says 'I don't know.' At 0:39, a civilian states 'I'm unarmed, not doing anything.' At 0:40, the officer asks 'You guys know where Andrew is at?' and a civilian identifies himself as 'Andrew.' At 0:44, a civilian says 'Good morning.' At 0:50, police radio chatter is heard. At 1:16, Andrew says 'I didn't do anything, it's my house.' At 1:18, the officer asks Andrew his name, and Andrew replies 'Richard.' At 1:25, a civilian says 'No, no interaction.' At 2:25, a female voice says 'He slapped another resident right before this.' At 2:42, the officer says 'Let's hook him up, take him in.' At 3:17, the officer tells Andrew 'You don't have any weapons on you do you? Turn around for me.' At 3:20, Andrew shouts 'I'm going to take you.' At 3:22, Andrew states 'I'm violently unable to.' At 3:29, Andrew pulls away, the officer calls for a 'Code 3, Taser.' Andrew says 'I'm going to tase you, dude. I'm going to freaking tase you. Get down.' The officer deploys the taser and Andrew screams in pain, shouting 'Nothing happened! What happened? F*** you!' At 3:41, the officer commands 'Turn around or you're gonna get hit!' Andrew yells 'Do it again! Do it again!' and 'No, officer!' At 4:26, Andrew yells 'Ah!' after another Taser deployment. Commands are repeatedly given for Andrew to turn around and put his hands behind his back.
audio_context_description: Outdoor ambient sounds are present throughout the video, including distant traffic and general neighborhood sounds. Police radio chatter is audible at various points. The most prominent audio cues are the verbal exchanges between officers and civilians, Andrew's shouts and screams of pain, and the distinct sound of a Taser deploying multiple times.
use_of_force_description: At 0:34, an officer made initial physical contact with a civilian (Andrew), possibly for a pat-down. At 3:20, the officer grabbed Andrew's arm to initiate physical detention. Andrew actively resisted this physical contact. At 3:34, an officer deployed a Taser on Andrew. This caused Andrew to fall to the ground. Andrew continued to resist verbally and did not fully comply with commands to turn over. At 3:45, the officer deployed the Taser for a second time while Andrew was on his hands and knees. At 3:55, the officer deployed the Taser for a third time while Andrew was on his stomach. At 4:30, the officer deployed the Taser for a fourth time while Andrew was lying on the ground, still not fully compliant with commands to turn over and put his hands behind his back.
compliance_and_behavior_description: Andrew initially verbally resisted identifying himself and stated 'I didn't do anything, it's my house' (1:16-1:17). He resisted commands to 'hang out here' (1:25-1:30) and walked away from the officers (1:48-1:53). When physical detention was attempted at 3:20, Andrew actively pulled away from the officer's grasp. After the first Taser deployment at 3:34, Andrew fell to the ground but did not fully comply with commands to turn around and put his hands behind his back. Instead, he verbally challenged the officer, shouting 'Do it again!' and 'F*** you!' while on the ground and in apparent pain.
excessive_force_description: Yes, there is potential for excessive force. The subject, Andrew, was tasered multiple times (at least four times at 3:34, 3:45, 3:55, and 4:30) while he was on the ground or in a semi-prone position. Although Andrew was non-compliant with commands to turn over and put his hands behind his back, he did not appear to be actively physically resisting in a manner that posed an immediate threat after the initial Taser deployment. Repeated Taser deployments on an incapacitated and non-threatening individual, even if non-compliant, could be considered excessive.
key_moments_summary: Officers arrived at a property searching for 'Andrew.' After initial verbal exchanges, Andrew identified himself. He initially resisted verbally and walked away when asked to stay put. At 3:20, an officer attempted to physically detain Andrew, who actively resisted. The officer deployed a Taser at 3:34, causing Andrew to fall. While on the ground and in apparent pain, Andrew did not fully comply with commands to turn around and put his hands behind his back, instead verbally challenging the officer. The officer deployed the Taser three additional times (at 3:45, 3:55, and 4:30) while Andrew remained on the ground, screaming and shouting, but not actively posing a physical threat.

speech_and_audio_cues_description: Officer commands the civilian to 'turn over,' 'all the way around,' 'hands behind your back,' 'all the way on your stomach,' and 'stay down.' The civilian responds with screams, yells of pain, and exclamations such as 'you dickhead,' 'no,' 'oh shit,' 'I have feeling all over around,' 'I can feel my brain,' 'I know I'm dead,' 'I gotta go hospital,' 'I can't breathe,' 'you're punching my back,' and 'I'm Japanese, bitch. I can't see you.' An officer states 'I don't want to tase you again' (5:19), implying prior taser use not shown in the clip. The officer also radios 'King 2, baton is ineffective' (7:23). Other officers make similar commands and remarks like 'He's pretty strong' (7:14) and 'Coming out with the cuffs' (8:36).
audio_context_description: The audio environment is dominated by human speech including clear commands from officers, and loud screams and exclamations of pain/distress from the civilian. There are distinct impact sounds from baton strikes and general ambient background noise consistent with an outdoor residential area.
use_of_force_description: An officer repeatedly used a baton, striking the civilian's legs, stomach, and potentially other areas. The first visible strike occurs around 5:23, followed by others at approximately 5:30, 5:33, 5:40, 5:45, 5:53, 6:00, 6:03, 6:08, 6:11, 6:19, 6:21, 6:28, 6:31, 6:35, 6:50, 6:51, 6:55, 6:57, 6:58, 6:59, 7:03, 7:07, 7:20, 7:21, 7:22, 7:41, 7:42, 7:44, 7:50, 7:51, 7:54, 7:58, 8:02, 8:03, 8:05, and 8:10. Multiple officers then engaged in physical contact to restrain the civilian on the ground, including kneeling on him. Handcuffs were applied from approximately 8:36 to 9:00 while the civilian was still resisting and expressing pain. The officer's statement 'I don't want to tase you again' at 5:19 suggests a taser was deployed prior to the start of this video segment.
compliance_and_behavior_description: The civilian, shirtless and with blood on his face at the start of the clip, was on the ground. He repeatedly failed to comply with commands to roll onto his stomach or put his hands behind his back. He verbally resisted, expressed extreme pain, and made some movements including attempting to kick (5:34-5:35). He claimed inability to comply due to pain ('I can't breathe,' 'I can't see you'). He was eventually restrained and handcuffed by multiple officers while still verbally expressing distress and pain.
excessive_force_description: The continuous and repeated application of baton strikes by the officer, specifically targeting the civilian's legs and stomach, appears potentially excessive given the civilian's prone position, visible injury (blood on face), and verbal expressions of extreme pain and inability to comply ('I can't breathe,' 'my brain'). The officer's statement at 7:23-7:24 that the 'baton is ineffective' further highlights the sustained nature of the force without achieving compliance, suggesting that the force was either not effectively applied or disproportionate to the level of resistance. The civilian continued to scream and express pain even after multiple officers arrived and during the handcuffing process, while being held down.
key_moments_summary: A shirtless civilian, already injured with blood on his face, is on the ground in a backyard. An officer repeatedly commands him to roll onto his stomach and put his hands behind his back. The civilian verbally resists, expresses extreme pain, and claims he cannot breathe or see. The officer repeatedly strikes the civilian with a baton, stating at one point that the 'baton is ineffective.' Additional officers arrive and physically restrain the civilian. The civilian continues to scream and express pain as he is eventually handcuffed by multiple officers while still on the ground.

speech_and_audio_cues_description: An officer states at 10:00, "Can you just put them on the ambulance?" The civilian groans from 10:01-10:05. An officer says "Camera on" at 10:05. An officer says "EMS is coming, EMS is coming here" at 10:06-10:07. The civilian continues to groan from 10:07-10:09. An officer asks "Can you calm down for me sir?" at 10:09-10:10. An officer asks "Do you have any concealed weapons or fire?" at 10:10-10:11. The civilian groans with a buzzing sound from 10:11-10:14.
audio_context_description: The audio consists primarily of human speech (officers and a civilian), a civilian groaning in apparent discomfort or pain, and a distinct buzzing sound later in the clip. There are also muffled sounds of movement.
use_of_force_description: At the beginning of the clip, at least two officers are engaged in physically restraining a civilian who is on the ground. The officers maintain physical control over the civilian's body. A buzzing sound is heard from 10:11-10:14 while the civilian is restrained and groaning.
compliance_and_behavior_description: The civilian is on the ground, actively groaning and expressing discomfort throughout the clip. They do not appear to be actively resisting by fighting or struggling, but their groans suggest distress or a lack of full cooperation with the restraint. Officers issue verbal commands, such as asking the civilian to calm down and inquiring about weapons.
excessive_force_description: The buzzing sound heard from 10:11-10:14 while the civilian is already restrained on the ground and groaning, particularly if it indicates a taser activation or application, could be considered a point of potential excessive force. The civilian does not appear to be actively resisting violent or threateningly at this stage, only expressing discomfort.
key_moments_summary: From 10:00-10:05, officers are seen restraining a groaning civilian on the ground, with an officer mentioning an ambulance. From 10:05-10:09, the restraint continues, EMS is called, and the civilian keeps groaning. From 10:09-10:11, an officer attempts to de-escalate by asking the civilian to calm down and checks for weapons. From 10:11-10:14, the civilian continues to groan while a buzzing sound is present.
